messages.content: What is the purpose of the Image Glitcher custom node in CrasHUtils?
The Image Glitcher custom node in CrasHUtils is used to apply glitch effects and chromatic aberration to images in ComfyUI. It is based on the HTML image glitcher by Felix Turner.
What are the parameters that can be adjusted in the Image Glitcher custom node?

In the Image Glitcher custom node, you can adjust the glitchiness, brightness, and add scanlines to the image. Glitchiness controls the amount of glitch corruption and chromatic aberration, brightness is useful when using scanlines, and scanlines add CRT TV style lines to the image.
What does the Color Stylizer custom node in CrasHUtils do?
The Color Stylizer custom node in CrasHUtils allows you to pick a single color in an image and greyscale everything else, keeping just the chosen color.
How can you use the Query Local LLM custom node in CrasHUtils?

To use the Query Local LLM custom node in CrasHUtils, you need to have the oobabooga API enabled in your oobabooga session. This node sends a query to the oobabooga API which runs local LLMs and outputs the response.
What is the purpose of the SDXL Resolution Picker custom node in CrasHUtils?
The SDXL Resolution Picker custom node in CrasHUtils allows you to choose from the pre-trained resolutions that SDXL supports. It provides a full list of supported resolutions to select from.
How does the SDXL Resolution Split custom node in CrasHUtils work?

The SDXL Resolution Split custom node in CrasHUtils converts the selected SDXL resolution into width and height values. This allows you to send your selected resolution with a single connection and split it out where needed, reducing the spaghetti lines in your ComfyUI setup.
What are the benefits of using the custom nodes provided by CrasHUtils in ComfyUI?

The custom nodes provided by CrasHUtils in ComfyUI offer additional functionality and flexibility for working with images and resolutions. They allow for easy application of glitch effects, color stylization, querying local LLMs, selecting SDXL resolutions, and splitting resolutions into width and height values.
